awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Algorithms, Incentives, and Information in Strategic Settings
awd_abstract_narration:
Much of today's economic activity and resource allocation takes place on systems with many strategic actors. Examples include auctions and exchanges for advertising space, matching markets for labor and capital, and congestion-aware GPS navigation systems. These systems have grown larger than ever before in today's networked world, and their behavior is necessarily a confluence of the preferences, beliefs, and strategic behaviors of many, rather than a system designer's intent. Nevertheless, there are two main "knobs" that a designer of such a system can turn in order to influence the equilibrium behavior of its participants: the incentives provided to players in the game, and the information available to them.

This proposal adopts the perspective of a designer looking to influence equilibrium outcomes in such systems. The proposed work will separately consider both modes of intervention, namely structuring the incentives provided and carefully revealing information. In each case, the PI will  examine the associated algorithmic question: Given the designer's objective, can a near-optimal intervention be computed efficiently? On the incentives front, the focus will be on refining existing theoretical models and algorithmic techniques with the goal of broadening their impact, in particular to settings where heuristic mechanisms and auctions have seen success in practice. On the information front, the proposed work will lay the foundations of an algorithmic theory of information in games, and begin a systematic examination of the computational complexity of intervention through information revelation.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

 

  We briefly describe the most notable results of the three major thrusts of this research.


Information Design:

This burgeoning area studies how information impacts the actions of strategic agents, and how to "design" the information to achieve desirable outcomes at game-theoretic equilibrium. This grant was concerned with the basic computational questions that arise thereof, and their implications: Are there efficient and/or simple algorithms for optimal information design? What lessons do these algorithms hold? Can the absence of such algorithms explain the lack of a structural understanding of optimal information structures in some settings?
 We made significant progress on these questions, laying the foundations of an algorithmic theory of information in games. We studied simple settings such as one agent trying to persuade another to take a desirable action (known as "Bayesian Persuasion"), to more intricate settings involving many heterogeneous agents such as auctions, voting, and routing.
 Of particular note are our results in the Bayesian Persuasion setting in [Dughmi and Xu, 2016], where we obtained optimal persuasion algorithms under some assumptions, and near-optimal persuasion algorithms more generally. Moreover, we ruled out exactly optimal algorithms in general, drawing novel connections to auction theory in the process. Also notable are our results on "public" information revelation in games involving many competing agents in [Cheng et al, 2015]. Here, we identify a pair of "smoothness" parameters of a game, and show that these parameters control the complexity of the associated information design problem. We also studied "private" information revelation in [Dughmi and Xu, 2017], whereby the game designer can send different information to different players. Here, we exhibit efficient and instructive algorithms which are approximately optimal for games satisfying a natural "no externality" property.

Mechanism Design:

This area is concerned with designing the rules of a game, known as a "mechanism", so as to yield desirable game-theoretic equilibria. The canonical applications here are resource allocation games such as auctions. The algorithmic study of mechanism design has seen an explosion of work over the last twenty years. This grant focused on technical and conceptual questions that have escaped prior work in this area, and we mention our most notable result next.
 The "holy grail" of algorithmic mechanism design is a generic procedure which turns efficient algorithms for resource allocation into efficient mechanisms with similar guarantees.  For problems where the goal is to maximize the aggregate utility of the participants, such a procedure was shown in prior work but with one caveat: the desirable outcome is obtained only at an "approximate equilibrium", leaving room for strategic manipulation by the participants. Removing this caveat has proven technically challenging, but we finally succeeded in doing so in [Dughmi et al, 2017]. We draw connections to the literature in probability theory on "Bernoulli Factories", concerned with exactly computing the output of a real-valued function given only "noisy" access to its input. In our work, we generalize that literature to functions whose output is a combinatorial object, and show that this generalization is precisely what was needed for algorithmic mechanism design.
 

Security Games:

This area is concerned with defending physical infrastructure from malicious attackers through game-theoretic modeling. The resulting "randomized patrolling" algorithms have been deployed to defend infrastructure throughout the United States. During the course of this grant, we applied insights from our work on information design to security games. In [Xu et al, 2015], we show how strategic information revelation can deter attacks on physical targets, improving upon existing solutions. In [Xu et al, 2015] and [Xu et al, 2018], we take the flip-side of this perspective, and examine whether existing game-theoretic solutions are brittle in the event of "information leakage" to an attacker due to, for example, insider threats or surveillance. We observe that that this is indeed the case, and develop algorithmic techniques for randomized patrolling that are resilient to such failures.

 

Broader Impact


The work funded by this grant played a major part in popularizing the study of computational questions pertaining to the information in strategic settings, as evidenced by hundreds of citations in followup work. Moreover, mid-way through this grant the PI wrote a survey article on computational information design which stimulated further interest in the topic.
 This grant has contributed to the training of several PhD and undergraduate students at USC. Two of the PhD students involved in the funded work are now tenure-track faculty in computer science at top-tier universities, and one undergraduate mentored by the PI is now a PhD student at a top computer science program.
 The line of work on information in security games has potential implications for national security. In particular, we implemented our algorithm for randomized assignment of air marshals to flights that is resilient to surveillance and insider threats. To our knowledge, this software has been delivered to the Federal Air Marshals Service (FAMS).
